hedline.hl1: Homeless Take Control of Their Lives on the Web

abstract.p: Article on homeless New York City people who are using computers in rescue missions and public libraries to surf Internet for jobs, build Web pages and use e-mail to reunite with family members; photo (M)

block.p: Back home in Puerto Rico, Angel Mora's family calls him Maestro, because he is so good with computers and because they are so proud of him.

Mr. Mora, 34, a former auto mechanic, cherishes the nickname, because when he walked into the New York City Rescue Mission nearly two years ago, the closest he had ever come to a computer was a pocket calculator.

Mr. Mora, 34, a former auto mechanic, cherishes the nickname, because when he walked into the New York City Rescue Mission nearly two years ago, the closest he had ever come to a computer was a pocket calculator.

By contrast, Shawn, a 28-year-old from New Jersey who preferred not to give his last name, regularly surfed the Internet before going to the mission a few months ago. He has since taught himself how to build a Web page.

Thanks to rescue missions and public libraries, a number of the city's 50,000 homeless people are finding the Internet. They are using it to get jobs and apply to colleges. They are building Web pages and using e-mail to reunite with family members. They do not have a physical address, but they are claiming a free and permanent one in cyberspace.
''It's reassuring to know you have a place that's yours, a way to get the basics,'' Shawn said. ''Some of these other homeless guys, how can they get a fax, a phone call?''
Mr. Mora and Shawn spend hours in the mission's Career and Learning Center, on Lafayette Street south of Canal Street, which is stocked with eight computers and books like ''Unleashing Unix.''

Most of the men at the mission have been out on the street less than a year, and one in five knew something about the Internet before winding up there, said Andy Duncan, who oversees the three-year-old computer center. The rest are eager to learn.

The men first take tutorials on typing and word processing. Then they are given e-mail accounts with Yahoo! or Hotmail, Mr. Duncan said. Most check their e-mail once or twice a week, but a few visit daily.
Mr. Mora is one such student. He downloads G.E.D. practice tests and looks up information about cars and about treating his diabetes. He sends e-mail to his niece and gets e-mail jokes from Shawn.

Shawn receives e-mail updates from Web sites like USAjobs.com, CareerMosiac, and How Stuff Works. He also swaps e-mail with friends who do not know he is homeless and with family members who do. He recently re-enrolled online for the fall semester at the New Jersey Institute of Technology after dropping out last year.

Until he goes back, he is posting his resume online. So far, three mission residents have found jobs through the Internet: Billy as a truck driver; Michael as a mortician; and another man who joined a pharmaceuticals company in New Jersey.
Homeless techies are also taking advantage of the public library.

''Someone who rents a book needs a physical address, but they can use any of the facilities without needing an identity,'' said Joanne King of the Queens Borough Public Library, explaining the allure.
Ned Richards of the New Amsterdam branch of the New York Public Library in Lower Manhattan said his homeless patrons preferred to be left alone.
''They are so smart, but a lot of them feel threatened by everything,'' he said.
